body: Would it be possible for you to send a pull request?

At the moment I solved the problem in my particular case by just preventing using unnecessary transforms with SpriteBatch. However "PureCpuSpriteBatch" implementation (without using GPU transform matrix at all) can generally be very useful. So I'll try find the time and prepare PR if you also consider such thing useful.

issue.title: Create PureCpuSpriteBatch.java
issue.body: PureCpuSpriteBatch only uses CPU transformations (so GPU transformMatrix is always identity). Based on CpuSpriteBatch to overcome #2630 problem.

body: xoppa please take a look on PullRequest. This is really just a simplified version of CpuSpriteBatch. I have just removed ability to change GPU used transformMatrix at all.

@titovmaxim Drawing a Group with scale 0 should be fine because the realMatrix is being inverted, not the group's transform. Normally each Group pushes its transform and pop it back after drawing, so the batch ends without altering the realMatrix. But if you're forcing a singular transform matrix _before_ drawing all bets are off. Is it a valid use case? What are you trying to accomplish?

@NathanSweet Making CpuSpriteBatch 'pure' would work. But we lose the optimization to `flushAndSyncTransformMatrix()` before drawing a large Group.

@vmilea I agree about Group transform scale 0. It is another situation. Imagine that a lot of buttons are drawn. The buttons "flies" (scales) from 0 to 1 when they appear and then back, when dissaper (not the group, but separate buttons). Some buttons have text label on the top and the from texture is different from the button texture. CPU sprite batch draw the button with scale 0, than it should draw the label. But it need to change texture. Therefore if flushes and 0 scale matrix become the real transform matrix. After that CpuSpriteBatch can not draw anything and the exception is thrown. That was my case.

Which is a better solution in your opinion? Either we can make it "pure" cpu, or make some estimations of matrix and copy it to real transform matrix only in the case it is "far" form singular (have scale more than some threshold, so it can be inverted without exception and significant lose of precision).

You're saying the real matrix gets synched due to `flush()`. But this was disallowed by commit faed79dd35b51dce9e109a5d3d56808d97d23506. The real matrix may be updated only on batch `end()` / `flushAndSyncTransformMatrix()`.

I checked with a tweaked [CpuSpriteBatchTest](https://gist.github.com/vmilea/6c233fb392e8924d26bd). Can you provide a self-contained example?

CpuSpriteBatch and SpriteBatch are both designed for 2D. There is no difference when using Affine2 to express the transformMatrix, assuming it's composed from 2D scale/translation/rotation primitives.

Translation in x-y plane (`trn(300f, 0f, 0f)`) is fine, but you shouldn't be tweaking the matrix directly. Use `Batch.setTransformMatrix()` instead.

@titovmaxim Thanks. To me this is valid usage.

I propose removing the automatic sync at `CpuSpriteBatch.end()`. Then the real matrix is never altered unless the user requests it explicitly via `flushAndSyncTransformMatrix()`.
